“On your bench press today, really lock in the slow lower. Count to 2 on the way down. This builds
strength and keeps your shoulders safe. Slowing things down gives your muscles more time under
tension and makes your joints more stable. If you rush, you miss out on a lot of the benefits.”

“When you Z Press today, lock your legs out and keep them flat. That forces your core to brace so
you can learn great mechanics of the shoulders and core during pressing movements. Starting in a
solid setup means less strain on your lower back and more strength built in the right places.”

REST DAY - Sunday

Happy Sunday, Functional Bodybuilders!

It's easy to get caught up in numbers, but how you move matters more than how much you move. Focus on quality first, and quantity will follow.

With Love,
Marcus

A) Coach Notes : As mentioned last week the first strength intensity section has increased by one
set, with the goal of matching the same weight as last week. The second strength intensity section
includes cossack squats. Remember cossack squats are a great exercise to get a quad pump BUT
also explore the frontal plane of motion and some unique angles at the ankle, knee, and hip.
Because of these unique angles, keep the weight light and focus on beautiful technique. The
strength balance has a similar intention as last week with some new movement variation. I am sure
you felt the pump in this section last week, try to hit the same stimulus this week. A more intense
hamstring option for the finisher today with nordic curls. When selecting a set up for the nordic
curls, try to be on the lower end of the rep scheme, with the goal of increasing total reps each
week you perform nordics.

A) Coach Notes: The strength intensity section today will include a tempo barbell bench press. The
tempo reads @22X1 - which means a 2 second lower, a 2 second pause in the bottom, normal
speed up, and a 1 second pause at the top. The goal of this tempo is to spend more time in the
eccentric and stretched part of this movement. By spending more time in these parts of the
movement we will maximize the muscle building from this exercise. The rep scheme today is
straight sets, which means you will perform the same repetitions for each set. The first set should
feel a little bit easier and then as the sets go on, it should start to feel harder because of the
accumulated fatigue. In the strength intensity 2 section you will see a new format. This is a
mechanical drop set. Pay close attention to the loading and progression notes to make sure that
you execute correctly. The strength balance and finisher sections will be a similar stimuli as last
week with a few new movements.

strength balance sections. The strength balance has two pushing exercises paired back to back.
This makes each one individually a bit more challenging. Make sure you are selecting weight to

A) Coach Notes: COACH NOTE –
Training Focus: Pull + Posterior Chain Strength
This session is designed to progressively develop your posterior chain across multiple fronts: hinge
mechanics, upper back hypertrophy, structural pulling strength, and arm isolation. Over the 6-week
cycle, you’ll see methodical progressions in both intensity and volume. We start with higher reps
and more controlled tempos early on to build quality and positional strength, then reduce volume
while increasing intensity as the cycle advances.
Strength Intensity 1 – Deadlift Progression
This 6-week deadlift wave alternates between Romanian Deadlifts (odd weeks) and Conventional
Deadlifts (even weeks) to balance control, position, and load tolerance.
RDL Weeks (1, 3, 5): You’ll begin with 10 reps and taper down to 4 reps over time. Tempo is set at
20X1, emphasizing control and time under tension through the posterior chain. RPE also rises
weekly (7 → 9), and reps fall (10/8/6 → 8/6/4).
Conventional Deadlift Weeks (2, 4, 6): These are steady-state sets with same weight across all sets.
You’ll start with 3x8, then 3x6, and finally 3x4, increasing intensity week to week. Focus on clean
bracing, bar speed, and symmetrical tension through the floor.
nervous system across consecutive weeks.
Strength Intensity 2 – Barbell & DB Row Progression
This is where we build serious upper back thickness and scapular control.
Barbell Row Weeks (1, 3, 5): You’ll start with 15-12-10 rep drop sets and finish with a back-off
AMRAP set. Volume decreases weekly while RPE increases, e.g., 15→10 reps and RPE 7→9. The
final set always returns to your first weight for max reps (targeting 10–15+).
DB Prone Row Weeks (2, 4, 6): Sets are kept static per week—Week 2 starts at 3x10, Week 4 drops to
3x8, and Week 6 finishes with 3x6—all at a 21X1 tempo, demanding scapular control. Each week
ends with a max effort set using the same working weight. This helps lock in control and
hypertrophy in a supported position.
This back-off structure helps drive adaptation without unnecessary fatigue while still building
strength and volume in the upper back.
Strength Balance – Pull-Up & Curl Supersets
These supersets serve two purposes: pulling pattern variety and elbow/bicep resilience.
Odd Weeks (1, 3, 5): You’ll use wide grip, commando, and narrow grip pull-ups across the weeks,
paired with various curls (crush grip, spider, hammer) for elbow flexor health and hypertrophy. Reps
trend from 4–6 → 6–10+, depending on grip and progression.
Even Weeks (2, 4, 6): The pull-up variations are paired directly with biceps work in a circuit format
(e.g., 4 rounds with 90 sec rest between). Use strict tempos to keep intensity up even at moderate
loads.
The progression here lies in volume density (less rest, higher intensity) and grip diversity, helping
with long-term structural balance and pull-up capacity.
Finisher – Posterior Chain + Core + Carry Work
These finishers help tie your pull mechanics together while reinforcing posture and core tension.
The format stays consistent (3 rounds, short rests), but the variation week-to-week builds capacity
across planes and postures. Expect a little breathing, a little shaking, and a lot of core recruitment.
Final Thoughts:
Respect the tempo work, hit clean reps with good posture, and stay patient in your progression.
Strength is earned in the subtle details—tempo, control, and volume accumulation.
Let your hinge and your upper back set the tone for the rest of your training week.
Short on Time? Take out the finisher.

A) Coach Notes: COACH NOTE Training Focus: Push (Chest + Triceps + Shoulder Health)
challenge horizontal pressing strength, muscular endurance, and shoulder positioning. Across the
six weeks, we rotate heavy mechanical tension, strict tempo control, and density-based accessory
work to maximize upper body pressing strength and shoulder integrity—without overloading the
same pattern.
This session balances:
-High-threshold pressing (tempo bench & dips)
-Pump/density volume (HSPUs, skullcrushers, lateral raises)
-Shoulder health and end-range strength (full raises, halos, face pulls)
Strength Intensity 1 – Bench Press / Incline Press
This wave alternates between flat tempo bench press (odd weeks) and incline variations (even
weeks) to train pressing strength across multiple angles.
Progression Details:
Odd Weeks – Tempo Bench Press:
Reps remain fixed at 3x5 @ tempo (3331 → 2221 → 21X1), with a fourth set as a no-tempo rep
out, targeting upper limit capacity.
Load stays consistent across sets, but tempo gets faster each week, letting bar speed increase as
time under tension decreases.
Goal: Move heavy-ish loads under strict control and then push to failure without tempo on final set
to drive overload.
Even Weeks – Incline Bench Press:
Reps drop week to week with the final set always repeating the first weight for an AMRAP set.
These weeks hit the mid-upper chest and anterior delts more directly, while giving the shoulder
joint slightly more freedom than flat bench pressing.
This alternating structure keeps the nervous system fresh, allows for better shoulder health, and
delivers progressive overload across angles and intent.
Strength Intensity 2 – Strict Dips & Push-Up Progressions
Odd weeks emphasize strict bar dips, progressing from 10s down to 6s with increasing RPE and a
final back-off AMRAP each week.
Even weeks shift to a triple push-up drop set progression to create metabolic fatigue.
The week-to-week focus is on maintaining rep quality across drop sets, reducing rest times, and
building pushing capacity under fatigue.
Strength Balance – HSPU, Lateral Raises, Posterior Delts
This tri-set is for shoulder durability and hypertrophy.
Odd Weeks (1, 3, 5) repeat the same:
Pike HSPU at strict tempo to build vertical pressing capacity
DB lateral raises with long eccentric tempos (30X0)
Face pulls to restore scapular positioning and rear delt volume
Even Weeks (2, 4, 6) introduce a more bodybuilding-style shoulder tri-set:
DB full raise → Poliquin raise → reverse fly, all at strict tempos
Focus here is deltoid isolation, shoulder centration, and pump-style fatigue
This balance between vertical push, side delt hypertrophy, and rear delt support gives you
well-rounded structural integrity and aesthetics.
Finisher – Push Volume + Arm Pump (6–8 min AMRAP)
Each finisher cycles between tricep-dominant pressing and supportive arm work.
Narrow grip pressing, dips, skullcrushers, and push-ups form the bulk of the engine.
Expect variations in volume and tempo across weeks, but the core goal is simple: light-moderate
load, short rest, continuous movement.
Week-to-week progression will naturally occur by completing more total reps or getting deeper into
each round.
Final Thoughts:
This push day isn’t just benching heavy—it’s about developing all angles of pressing strength,
shoulder health, and tricep drive. Every block builds on the last: tempo → speed → density →
fatigue. Don’t skip the warm-up or shoulder balance work—they’re what let you keep pressing
strong without nagging aches.
Get crisp reps early, get gritty reps late, and finish with a pump.
Short on Time? Take out Strength Intensity 2 or the Finisher based on your goals.

A) Coach Notes: COACH NOTE –
Training Focus: Full Body (Hip Hinge + Horizontal Press + Lower/Glute Balance + Core Integration)
Today’s session is hinge-dominant with supportive pushing and posterior chain work. The layout is
designed to build glute and hamstring strength through Romanian or conventional deadlifts,
supported by pressing variations. Lower body structural balance work follows, and we close with a
rotational core finisher.
This session targets:
Posterior chain development (RDL/Deadlift)
Strict bodyweight pushing strength (Dips or Push-Up complexes)
Lower body symmetry and glute engagement
Core control through rotational and anti-extension challenges
Strength Intensity 1 – Romanian or Conventional Deadlifts
This progression rotates weekly to build both hinge mechanics and load tolerance. Use tempo
intentionally on RDL weeks to lengthen and load hamstrings. On deadlift weeks, lock in position
and groove pull from the floor.
Intention: Drive the hips back, keep lats locked, and control the eccentric.
Strength Intensity 2 – Strict Dips or Push-Up Progressions
Strict bar dips alternate with advanced push-up tri-sets to load triceps, chest, and shoulders
through clean pressing mechanics. Use tempo to maintain control and maximize time under
tension.
Goal: Develop vertical pressing strength and muscular endurance.
Intention: Keep shoulder blades down and chest proud—no slouching at the bottom.
Strength Balance – Landmine Hack Squats + Glute Pumps or Step Variations
Split stance, box work, and glute pumps bring symmetry, joint control, and glute fatigue. Don’t rush
this—form is everything here.
Goal: Create structural balance between quads, glutes, and posterior chain.
Intention: Keep heel rooted and push through the full foot—quality over speed.
Finisher – Core & Shoulder Integration
Movements change weekly, but the goal stays the same: load the core while moving through
control-based ranges. Turkish sit-ups, chops, and deadbugs integrate breath, stability, and
coordination.
Goal: Strengthen the midline and reinforce posture under fatigue.
Intention: Stay connected to your breath. Move slowly and with purpose.
Final Thoughts
Today’s session hits the hinge hard, with tricep and glute fatigue layered on top. Respect the tempo,
stay tight through the pull, and don’t underestimate the quality needed in push-up or dip work.
This day is built to reinforce durability and build powerful hips.
Hinge strong. Press clean. Finish with fire.
Let’s go.

This upper session continues our push-pull upper body format with a vertical emphasis. The goal is
to refine overhead mechanics, build tricep-dominant pressing strength, and layer in pulling
variations that challenge grip, core control, and scapular retraction. The structure balances strict
tempo strength, positional stability, and functional isolation to create strong, durable shoulders
and arms.
This session targets:
Vertical pressing strength and postural control (Z Press + Filly Press)

pressing strength.

Coach cue: Don’t cheat the tempo. Full hang, full pull, and control the eccentric.

a technician, finish with grit.

A) Coach Note: COACH NOTE – Friday, September 26, 2025
Training Focus: Full Body – Horizontal Push, Single-Leg Hinge, Shoulder Balance, Core + Carry
Integration
This Friday session rounds out the 3x/week PUMP LIFT cycle with an upper-body push focus and
single-leg posterior chain training. We’re progressing horizontal pressing strength through tempo
and incline variations while layering in unilateral hinging, shoulder balance work, and carry-based
trunk stability. Expect moderate loads with strict tempo and intentional control throughout each
section.
Strength Intensity 1 – Tempo Bench Press / Incline Press
This pressing wave alternates weekly between strict tempo bench press (Weeks 1, 3, 5) and incline
pressing (Weeks 2, 4, 6) to develop horizontal pressing strength, scapular control, and pressing
endurance. Tempo variations challenge different phases of the lift, while the incline work
introduces new pressing angles and fatigue tolerance.
Odd Weeks: Tempo Bench Press – 3331 → 2221 → 21X1 progression with final AMRAP set (no
tempo)
Even Weeks: Incline Bench Press with descending reps and a back-off volume AMRAP
Coach Cue: Use the tempo to build control through the full range. Feel the stretch at the bottom
and don’t rush the pause—tempo drives results here.
Strength Intensity 2 – Single-Leg DL + Calf Work
This lower-body segment targets unilateral hip hinging and ankle strength. Landmine and KB
deadlift variations develop posterior chain stability and balance, while the calf raise or
athleticism.
Odd Weeks: Landmine Single-Leg DL + Landmine Calf Raise (with tempo)
Even Weeks: KB Single-Leg DL + stability core or shoulder accessory
Coach Cue: Ground through your big toe and brace your core. Move slow through the hinge and
finish tall—own the balance and drive through the hip.
Strength Balance – HSPU / DB Raise Series / Face Pulls
This tri-set balances out pushing volume by emphasizing deltoid development and scapular
retraction. Odd weeks favor vertical pushing (Pike HSPU), while even weeks progress through DB
raise sequences to challenge all angles of the shoulder complex.
Odd Weeks: Pike HSPU + Lateral Raise + Face Pull
Even Weeks: DB Full Raise + Poliquin Raise + Bent-Over Reverse Fly
Coach Cue: This is where shoulder integrity is built. Stay tall through the torso, use a light weight
to isolate tension, and don’t rush through the reps.
Finisher – Pullover, Carry, Plank
A 3-part circuit focused on trunk stiffness, shoulder positioning, and isometric strength. Each week,
the loading implement (DB, KB, cable) is adjusted to vary the stimulus.
Odd Weeks: DB or KB Pullover + Goblet/Dual KB Carry + Extended Plank
Even Weeks: Cable/Band Pulldown + Shrugs or Hollow Rock + Single-Leg or Single-Arm Plank
Coach Cue: Finish strong by staying intentional in your breath and bracing. Keep your ribcage down
on the pullover, upright in the carry, and locked in during the plank.
Final Thought:
This session is all about controlled intensity. Keep your form dialed, embrace the tempo, and use
the accessories to build bulletproof shoulders and a rock-solid core to carry into next week.
Short on Time? Take out the finisher.

A) Coach Notes: COACH NOTE –
Training Focus: Lower – Split Squat Strength, Posterior Chain Volume, Glute Dominance, Rotational
Variability
We’re closing out the training week with a split-stance focused lower body day, emphasizing
unilateral strength. The primary lift alternates between ipsilateral RFESS and back-rack split squats
across the 6-week cycle, both performed with strict tempo to reinforce stability, strength, and knee
resilience. Hip thrusts follow as a high-rep glute finisher, while balance work and aerobic
bodybuilding tie it all together with rotational, lateral, and continuous effort demands.
This session targets:
Split-stance loading + tempo strength (RFESS, Split Squats)
Posterior chain hypertrophy (Hip Thrusts, Sumo Deadlifts, GMs)
Frontal and transverse plane stability (Cossack, Kickstand, Curtsy)
Aerobic capacity meets hypertrophy (Bike/Row circuits + KB flow work)
Strength Intensity – Split Squat + Hip Thrust Superset
Odd weeks cycle through ipsilateral suitcase RFESS, while even weeks utilize the back-rack split
squat. Tempo (20X1) is consistent to build positional strength, and volume descends weekly from
12s to 6s before finishing with a rep-out set in Week 6. Hip thrusts follow every week to hammer
glute development and posterior chain fatigue tolerance.
Coach cue: Keep hips squared, ribs tucked, and eyes forward. Your rear foot should be a
support—not a crutch.
Strength Balance – Tempo Unilateral Work
This segment brings in tempo-dominant accessory work to reinforce glute med control, hamstring
engagement, and lateral/transverse plane mechanics. Pairings rotate weekly to include Cossack
squats, suitcase curtsy squats, and split stance good mornings, always performed at a controlled
30X0 tempo.
Coach cue: Don’t rush the descent—find tension, maintain posture, and let your glutes do the work.
Conditioning – Aerobic Lower Body Bodybuilding
and muscular endurance simultaneously. Whether in EMOM or continuous format, these circuits
layer traditional conditioning with tempo KB movements, kneeling transitions, and midline
engagement to drive long-range lower body stamina.
Coach cue: Match your breathing with your movement, especially during transitions. Stay smooth,
stay moving.
Final Thoughts
You’ll press, pulse, and push through every plane, one leg at a time. Lock into tempo early, find your
rhythm in the hip thrusts, and let your effort carry through conditioning. The legs will be torched
by the end, but the structure will carry over into every movement next week.
Short on Time? Decrease Conditioning Time Cap to 10 minutes.

A) Coach Notes: Today is a lower body day focusing primarily on the squat movement pattern.
The Strength Intensity 1 section alternates between a traditional back squat and a cyclist front
squat. The back squat can be a very demanding exercise; for this reason, it can be beneficial to
perform every other week - like this training block. This assures you are fully recovered going into
your back squat session and can bring 100% effort. If you have been squatting for a long time, you
know what having a bad day under the bar is like. Not only is it brutal mentally, but you are
exposing yourself to more injury risk. Although it might not be enough training volume to squat
only once every other week, performing a demanding back squat only once every other week can
be a great way to continue to see progress in the back squat for a long time. In between back squat
sessions, we will use the front squat on this day (which is less taxing on the body), and we will be
using other squat variations on Day 4 of this training block.
The Strength Intensity 2 section pairs a walking lunge and a core exercise. Performing lunges after
your squats is a great way to have a better feel for the quads and the glutes. You can generally feel
a stronger stimulus because some fatigue is already built up in these areas. Try not to shy away
from that stimulus because of fatigue; push into those tired areas because we seek strength and
growth. Use lighter weights if you feel yourself compensating or moving away from these tired
muscles.
The Strength Balance today is a perfect balance for the work up to this point in the training day.
The first section was quad-dominant, and now it is time for the hamstrings to get involved. The
hamstring exercise will be performed alone because using these machines and other equipment
options can be challenging. Many potential substitutes exist if you do not have a GHD or hamstring
Hamstring Curl, a Physio Ball Hamstring Curl, Slider Hamstring Curls, or BC Gliding Hamstring
Curls. These options require very little equipment to perform and stimulate the hamstrings well.
The Finisher section targets some of the smaller muscles in isolation. The calves, adductors, and
glute med will all be a focus in this section. After the big compound movements earlier in the
training session, it generally feels great for the body to perform smaller isolated exercises like what
is found in this finisher section.

Yesterday was a leg day, and you may have some residual soreness in the quads or hamstrings.
Today, we will target the glutes, but isolating them without involving the hamstrings is difficult. For
this reason, we are using exercises that require a different type of contraction than yesterday.
Yesterday's hamstring work focused on bending the knee (shortening the hamstring), and today, we
will focus on lengthening the hamstring, primarily at the hip. The first Strength Intensity section
will pair a single-leg hip hinge and shoulder raise variation. The single-leg hip can provide a great
stimulus to the glutes because of the demand for balance. If you are sore from yesterday, keep your
weight moderate, go slow, and emphasize control and balance to get a good stimulus. If your glutes
and hamstrings are not sore, you can push the stimulus a little harder and load this exercise up. We
recommend using weightlifting straps if you struggle to grip the barbell well. The single-leg RDL
will transition to a split stance RDL in week 4 of this training block.
The Strength Intensity 2 section is our primary shoulder exercise for today. The Barbell Z Press will
be used for the first three weeks to establish good core engagement during the overhead press. Try
to apply that technique to the traditional strict press that will be performed in weeks 4-6. Pay close
attention to the reps and sets each week. Like the pull-ups from Day 1, the TEMPO and rep scheme
will change each week.
The Strength Balance section will be the primary arm section for today's training. The movement
and reps will stay the same for the first three weeks, with the progressive overload coming through
one additional set each week. This is a very valuable and very underutilized method for building
strength. In the final three weeks of this section, you will perform a different bicep and tricep
exercise to increase total reps with the same weight week over week.
The Finisher section includes classic abdominal exercises that work well for high volumes. These
are paired with a rear delt exercise.
Short On Time? There are many options to adjust the workout today. Skip the section that is least
in alignment with your goals. If you want this to be a primarily upper body day today, skip the
Strength Intensity 1 section. If you want a shoulder focus, skip the Strength Balance section.
Remove the finisher if you do not want to focus on the abs.

cyclist front squat. The back squat can be a very demanding exercise; for this reason, it can be
beneficial to perform every other week - like this training block. This assures that you are fully
recovered going into your back squat session and can bring 100% effort. If you have been squatting
for a long time, you know what having a bad day under the bar is like. Not only is it brutal mentally,
but you are exposing yourself to more injury risk. Although it might not be enough training volume
to squat only once every other week, performing a demanding back squat only once every other
week can be a great way to continue to see progress in the back squat for a long time. We will use
other squat variations between back squat sessions to get a similar stimulus without being too
demanding.
